msItem.note: Fols. i–1 are originally blank paper and parchment flyleaves (see Provenance).

msItem.title: 1 Ezra, without a prologue–2 Maccabees in the Later Version of the Wycliffite Bible
msItem.note: With usual prologues. Includes a gloss ioob was a very man in kinde…, written in red as a rubric at the beginning of Job (fol. 36r) (see also MSS. Bodl. 296 and Fairfax 2). Running titles on both rectos and versos, consisting of abbreviated titles of books only. Rubrics in red, e.g., Here endeþ þe firste book of esdre & here bigynneþ þe ij book of esdre (fol. 7v). Chapter numbers in red Roman numerals and in brown ink as Roman or Arabic numerals by the scribe. Added material within the text is consistently underlined in red. Red paraphs at the beginnings of sections within the text. Corrections in the margins or over erasures in the original or contemporary hands. Rubrics in Esther and Daniel pointing out the differences between the Hebrew and Latin texts. A few glosses in the margins, some with a rubric A glos (fol. 37r). Occasionally cross-reference to biblical books in the margins. At the end of Job: Here endiþ þe book of Iob. blessid be þe hooly Trynyte Amen (fol. 50v). The final lines of the second column on fol. 50v are left blank, and psalms start on a new leaf of the same quire in textura (see Script).

Rubric Here bigynneþ þe sauter which is red comynli in chirchis at the beginning of psalms. Psalms start with 2-line initials and are written as prose with verses beginning with alternating red or blue initials. Each psalm is preceded by a title and Latin incipit in the margin; there is a running title Sauter. Larger initials at psalms 26, 38, 52, 68, 80, 97 and 109. Psalm 118 is subdivided into twenty-two sections with Latin incipits of sections written in the margins.
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeþ the secounde book of Machabeis. Blessid be þe hooly trinyte (fol. 229v, see Provenance)
msItem.note: About a half of the second column at the end is left blank.
Fols. 230–231 are blank parchment and paper flyleaves.

supportDesc.collation: (fols. i–1) paper and parchment flyleaves | (fols. 2–225) I– XXVIII (8) | (fols. 226–229) XXIX (4) | (fols. 230–232) paper and parchment flyleaves. Medieval leaf signatures survive; quire signatures, probably contemporary with the present binding, run A–Z, Aa–Ee. foure hundrid (fol. 3r)

layoutDesc.layout: ruled for two columns with double (fols. 2–50) and single (fols. 51–229) vertical and horizontal bounding lines extending the full height and width of page; 46 (fols. 2–50) and 48 (fols. 51–229) lines per page; written space: c. 250 140

handDesc.handNote: Anglicana (fols. 2–50); textura (fols. 51–229); black and brown ink

decoDesc.decoNote: 4- to 7-line red and blue ‘puzzle’ initials decorated with red and purple penwork at the beginnings of books. An initial on fol. 28v has anthropomorphic decoration.
2- to 3-line blue initials with red penwork at the beginnings of prologues and chapters.

binding.p:
Brown leather over thick pasteboard, 18th century. Double blind fillet-line border round the outer edge of both covers. Rectangular figure at the centre of both covers made of blind-roll floral designs with floral corner-pieces. Eight raised bands on spine. Paper label on spine with handwritten ‘D. 4. 1’. Fragment of another paper label at the bottom of the spine. Gilt lettering at the bottom of the spine: ‘MS.
C. C. C.
20’. Edges of textblock speckled red. Paper pastedowns and flyleaves.

origin.p: No evidence that the manuscript is deficient at the end; perhaps originally a two-volume Old Testament.

Dialect survey:
eny(1)/ony(4), ech(9)/eche(1), fier(10), ȝoue(5)/ȝouun(5), liyf(10), liyk(10), myche(8), siȝ(8) (sg.), seien(2)/sien(6) (pl.), silf(10), þouȝ(2), þorouȝ(2)
-iþ(8)/-eþ(2) (pres.ind.3sg.), -en(10) (pres.ind.pl.), -ynge(6)/-inge(2)-ing(1) (pres.part.), sche(3) (3sg.fem.pronoun, nom.), þei(10) (3pl.pronoun, nom.), hem(10) (3pl.pronoun, oblique), her(10) (3pl.pronoun, possessive)

history.provenance: per me Nicholam Hill, ffrauncis vaughan, 16th century (fol. 1v).
Colophon on fol. 229v is followed by an added date in a 16th-century hand: wylke was endet in yᵉ ȝyez of oure lord a thousand and ij hundert (fol. 229v).
history.acquisition: At Corpus Christi College, Oxford by 1697 (listed in Bernard’s catalogue of 1697). Earlier shelfmarks: ‘D. 4. 1.’ (upper pastedown, spine); ‘Nº. 1487. 20 D. 4. 1.’ (fol. 1v).

recordHist.source: Elizabeth Solopova, Manuscripts of the Wycliffite Bible in the Bodleian and Oxford College Libraries, Exeter Medieval Texts and Studies (Liverpool: Liverpool University Press, 2016), no. 52.

listBibl.bibl: Bernard, E., Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliae et Hiberniae in unum collecti cum indice alphabetico (Oxford 1697).

Forshall, J. and Madden, F. (eds), The Holy Bible … in the earliest English versions made from the Latin Vulgate by John Wycliffe and his followers, 4 vols (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1850), vol. 1, pp. li–lii; siglum H.

Coxe, H. O., Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque Oxoniensibus hodie adservantur, 2 vols (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1852), vol. 2, Catalogus codicum MSS. Collegii Corporis Christi, p. 5. Deanesly, M., The Lollard Bible and other medieval biblical versions (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1920), p. 334.
Hargreaves, H., ‘The Latin text of Pervey’s psalter’, Medium Aevum 24 (1955), pp. 73–90 at p. 88 n. 26.
Hudson, A., Selections from English Wycliffite writings (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1978), pp. 164–5.
Ogilvie-Thomson, S. J., Index of Middle English prose, 18 vols (Cambridge, 1984– ), Handlist VIII (1991), p. 19.
Dove, M., The first English Bible: the text and context of the Wycliffite versions (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007), pp. 18, 96, 106, 156, 183, 220, 229, 261–2, 302.
Thomson, R. M., A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Corpus Christi College Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 2011), pp. 8–9.
